*out of the box*: I'm really not into reviewing animes. I watched a lot. There were many times I cried, smiled and got goosebumps. Neverthought I would write one But here I am. This anime made me do IT.\n\n\n\n

If your granddaughter has eye problems, what do you do? Go to the optometrist? Nope! Send her back in time to have a high school life with your past self. This is basically Irozuku Sekai no Ashita Kara's story. Sounds stupid? Yeah it is. 
There is no real story. Every episode we are reminded that Hitomi cannot see colors. She tries a bunch of impractical methods (even in the context of magic) to get it back. A lot of chessy predicable high school romance drama.
The characters are all pretty much souless except for Kohaku. Every episode Hitomi just goes "I can't do it, I hatemagic." Every character is a log. 


Visuals and animation were great, but that's all you get if you want anything else. It is boring and the I don't want to fault the voice acting because the script was probably so bland they couldn't insert personality into the voices.


You aren't losing anything from not watching this.

This is the first review I've ever given. I was compelled to, after seeing the low rating and some of the reviews.
I've watched a lot of anime, and I was personally offended by the low rating and the negative reviews. I'm taking it upon myself to strongly recommend the anime to those on the fence, it's definitely worth watching.
This show is best enjoyed when binged. This is partly what I blame for the low ratings. The development and impact of the anime is lost in the weekly format.
This is a feelzy atmospheric anime, it makes you feel good inside. I personally enjoyed the subtle romanceaspect of it the most. The anime gets very generic at some parts (mostly in the middle few episodes). But it's worth it to stick with it till the end. Try not to pick the plot apart, it's not about the plot as much (It's still a good plot, just not the most compelling plot), it's about the character development. The anime has a beautiful ambiance and a pleasant soundtrack. Character designs are downright gorgeous. The animation is spectacular.\n\n
If you're into subtle youthful love and romance, with a slight magical / fantasy element with some brilliant ambiance, this is the anime for you. I went into it with low expectations looking at the rating and the reviews. The fact that I'm going out of my way writing this review should give you an idea of how worth it it is to watch this anime. Highly recommended.

What would you do if one day your grandmother, who is also a mage, would come up to you and say she is going to send you 60 years into the past? This is the beginning of the story of Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara, an anime where the colour blind Hitomi Tsukishiro gets send into the past to find her true self.
Story: 7/10
Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara starts in 2078 with Hitomi Tsukishiro who is at a festival looking at fireworks, thinking about the time she was watching them with her mother and could still see them in colour. She meets up with hergrandmother who pretty suddenly sends her 60 years into the past in order to experience a different kind of life. In 2018 Hitomi Tsukishiro lands in the house of Yuito Aoi, as her journey in another time starts. Sometimes she is able to see colour in this time, especially when she looks at Yuito's drawings, which is the only thing she sees in colour. The premise of Irozuku sets up for a pretty interesting story having to do with time travel, magic, colour blindness and the theme of finding yourself again. The story does have some inconsistencies, with its time travel for example and some random conveniences like Hitomi landing in the house of Yuito, even though you would probably land in the same place as where you left if you only travel through time. It is also pretty convenient that she can only see colour in Yuito's drawings, but this could maybe be explained by them being linked by magic or something similar. The story is also very slow in some episodes, making it feel more like a slice of life show with a bit of magic (in those episodes). The story does have some interesting themes to tell though. The theme of the difference between seeing colour or not is an interesting one for example, as the anime really shows the difference between seeing colour or not, as well as Hitomi's colour blindness having to do with her emotions. She probably unconsciously used magic on herself to make her colour blind, although it is not really explained. There is also the theme of going further with your life. After Hitomi's past experiences she has become stuck in the past, making her grandmother send her to the past, giving her the life experiences she needs to go further with her life and develop more. Conclusively, the story has an interesting premise, some inconsistencies and conveniences here and there, but overall has pretty good themes to tell.


Art and animation: 9/10

This anime looks very beautiful overall. You can see that P.A. Works put a lot of time in making the different backgrounds look very detailed, colourful and pretty beautiful.  Hitomi eventually is also able to enter the world of drawings in which she can see the colours. In these different drawings you can really see the work that has been put into making them look pretty special and beautiful, as well as putting some abstractness into the drawings.  There is also a good use of seeing the world in colour vs seeing the world from the perspective of Hitomi, when it is black and white. This also seen very well in the opening. The only real downside to the art and animation is the somewhat bad looking CGI used for some of the background characters and vehicles. Overall the animation is very beautiful and you can really see that a lot of effort has been put into it.


Sound: 7/10

The overall music used in the anime is very well done. The opening theme is pretty nice and shows the atmosphere of the anime well. The use of music throughout the anime itself is also well done, as it fits well with the different scenes. There was a lack of soundtracks which stood out to me though. The voice actors also did a pretty good job voicing the different emotions of the characters. This is especially seen with Hitomi, where you can clearly hear that she is pretty shy and with her grandmother in 2018, who sounds really energetic most of the time. Overall the sound in the anime is pretty well done.


Characters: 6/10

Although Hitomi and Kohaku (Hitomi's grandmother (in 2018)) are pretty interesting characters and get some development, the other characters in the anime feel a bit one dimensional and often have conflicts which seem to be solved too quickly. One of the characters has a romance conflict for example, so Hitomi goes to her and talks a bit and she seems almost instantly over it afterwards. Yuito just likes to draw and does not seem to have any other interests in the anime and one of the characters randomly fall in love with Hitomi and does not seem to have any particular interests except liking photography. Hitomi is a pretty shy character and colour blind for many years, which she blames on her magic abilities. She looks to be stuck in the past and finds new friends and life experiences throughout the series, giving her world colour. She also gets better at her magic ability and stops hating on it. Kohaku is a pretty energetic character and often part of the more comedic moments of the anime. She makes for a pretty nice character and fits well in contrast to Hitomi. Overall the characters are decent, the main characters are pretty good, but the side characters are pretty one dimensional.


Enjoyment: 7/10

Overall this anime was pretty enjoyable for me. It has an interesting premise, some nice character moments from the main characters a pretty good soundtrack and great animation to look at. Especially the moments in the world of the drawings were very enjoyable for me to watch due to its unique animation and special feeling it gave of. It was also interesting to think about how the time travelling would work out in the anime and it had a few interesting themes.


Bonus categories: 6/10

-----

Romance: 6/10

If you like a lot of romantic progression, this anime is not the right one for you. You have the typical situation of one character liking another character, who likes another character, who likes another character. The main romance also does not really progress a lot, although the romance in the anime does make for a few nice moments.


Tragedy: 7/10

The anime has plenty pretty tragic moments and heartwarming moments being able to make someone pretty emotional. It did not do it for me, but I can understand that many people were able to get emotional because of a few scenes in the anime.


Time travel: 5/10

The time travel in this anime was not very logical (which could be expected, because it is done with magic). It seemed as if there was only one timeline in the anime, as Kohaku in 2078 has the memories of meeting Hitomi in 2018. This seems weird, as Kohaku got the idea to send Hitomi to the past from meeting Hitomi in 2018. Without using alternate timelines this would result in a paradox, but if alternate timelines were used there would be the question of how Kohaku got the idea of sending Hitomi into the past in the first place. Besides that the time travel is also used very convenient for the plot (seen with Hitomi landing in Yuito's room when he almost enters the room for example).

-----


Overall: 7/10

Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara is a pretty good anime overall. It has an interesting premise and a story with some inconsistencies and conveniences, but some very interesting themes. It also has great art and animation and a pretty good soundtrack. The main characters were pretty interesting, although the side characters were a bit one dimensional. It also had some romance and some tragic moments. However, its time travel aspect could be improved on. All and all it was a pretty good and enjoyable anime.

Quick summary of the review : 
In my opinion Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara turned out to just be an okay show with pretty visuals, and could have been better if its main focus was on only one theme : 13 episodes weren't enough to develop all the things (friendship, romance, drama moments) they wanted to.
Art :
The visuals are pretty : the sceneries are beautiful and the scenes with magic are well done. The colors in this show have quite a big importance and the scenes where they are particularly meaningful are gorgous.  My only regret on this is that I find their facesa little weird (their eyes).


Sound :

The OST are not bad, but I didn't hear one that I particularly liked. However, I can say that they made efforts with the sound effects.


Story, character and enjoyment :

This section contains a general description of how the anime is developped, and as such may contains spoilers.


After watching the last episode of Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara, I'm under the impression that this show was trying to development too many subjects at once, resulting in a feeling that it was all over the place :


Indeed, there are 3 main themes that are easily identifiable in this anime : friendship, romance and Hitomi's evolution.

In my opinion this anime is aiming to be quite 'serious' (you wouldn't take this show as lightly as a romcom or a slice of life anime, for example), and from episode 1 you can already guess that there will be really sad moment near the end. However, Irozuku is only 13 episodes long : it's difficult to properly develop these themes within such a short time and keeping with the high expectations of the viewer. And this is where lies the problem :



*********** if you absolutely do not want to be spoiled skip this part ***********


The final episode contains a scene where it's the time of farewells between Hitomi and her friends. This scene is the climax in terms of feels, but I had trouble to feel the sadness as the relationship between the characters isn't fully developped throughout the season, and thus it's difficult to feel the bond between them because in the end we don't know characters well. Nonetheless, this scene is still quite intense but it could have been way, way better if they properly built the feels up to this point.

Maybe they didn't want to finish on a too sad ending? The rest of the episode focuses on Hitomi who has clearly accepted that she leaved her friends and keeps them as precious memories, and is already taking steps towards a new future for her, where she gained more confidence and is able to fully appreciate life.


The same thing is true for the romance, as it is born kind of out of nowhere (it was not an instant love for the two sides) between Hitomi and Yuito. I didn't saw them fall in love with each other progressively : I'm under the impression that they just admitted that they have feeling for each other at some point of the show. There are others romance in the group but they are so underdevelopped that they are not worth mentionning.


There is also the problem with Hitomi's monochromatic vision that is not fully explained by the end of the series : the source of this is probably a magic unconsciously casted by Hitomi on herself as conjectured by Kohaku. In the end it's finally dispelled, and it's easy to deduce that it's because she finally relearned how to appreciate life. 

However we still don't know how it was casted, and why there are moments where it's quite selectively cancelled, like the moment where the fireworks are launched at the end of the school festival : why are the fireworks the only things that Hitomi sees in color at that moment? Shouldn't at least her friend also be, since she mentionned that she feels happy that she could do something with them?


************************* end of potential spoilers ************************



In contrary, the development of Hitomi's personnality from the beginning to the end is quite good, although it feels a little lacking : we witness Hitomi growing more and more accustomed to her new surroundings (and her new friends) and taking more initiatives compared to her old self.


In the end this show still is enjoyable but it isn't as good as it could have been.

So much wasted potential...
You can tell that Irozoku was trying for the feels, similar to series like Anohana or Angel Beats, however, it couldn't quite reach that point. Not to say that it was bad. It just didn't draw the viewer in enough to make me invested in any of the characters. Therefore, I didn't feel anything during the climax of the story. Perhaps I'm just heartless, but that's truly what I experienced when watching this show.
*Non-Spoiler Review*
The series was going for a beautiful lifetime experience that develops the characters in a positive way, with a touching and emotional climax. While it isn't anything new,I still appreciated the fact that a series of this format was made. Yet, sadly, this series wasn't able to fully deliver on that experience. Perhaps it lacked time, but personally, I think that the later episodes just turned out to be too mellow. With an interesting premise such as this, I think they could have done a lot more with the story to make it engaging.


The art is very good, and is probably the best thing about this anime. You can clearly tell that the animators put in a lot of work to make this look good, and it does.


To me, the characters lacked any real depth to them, which is probably why I couldn't invest myself in them. They're all just generally far too nice to be human, and that ends up being detrimental to the purpose of the story.


Sad to say that this anime couldn't deliver on what I expected from reading the synopsis. If you haven't seen any shows of this nature, then maybe this anime is a good start. However, if you've seen any of the anime I mentioned previously, or any other anime that I haven't mentioned which have a similar premise, then I would recommend watching something else. It's a nice anime to look at, but not one to enjoy.


Thank you for reading this review!

The theme of transience is often expressed in Japanese culture as "mono no aware." For the uninitiated, mono no aware is roughly translated as "the pathos of things," a Zen mood essential to several Japanese traditions, such as hanami (cherry blossom viewing). Both Ozu and Shinkai heavily transmit the concept, but one of my favourite examples of mono no aware in cinema is in Edward Yang's Yi Yi. There's a part in which NJ, the father of the Jian family on whom the film focuses, spends a whole 24 hours exploring Tokyo with his ex-lover during a business trip. They walk through a shrine, bythe beach, on the streets, all the while catching each other up on their lives since they had last been together and, eventually, talking over their past romance, its dissolution, and the resulting emotional trauma. It's a brilliant illustration of mono no aware, as even though the two reflect on the past, they are portrayed in this time as their selves, in the current, in their respective lives, having grown apart. Irozuku attempts to arouse this same wistful projection of the past onto the moment of the now in a very strange, roundabout manner.


The premise of Irozuku is convoluted in the sense that it combines two frameworks, time traveling and school life, as a means to a telos not commonly seen in either. The two employ elements already at odds with each other. Time travel imbues a story with dramatic irony and direction by establishing an ending inherent in the beginning: the audience knows the time traveler must inevitably return to their timeline. School anime tend to be slice of life comedies, which is a genre known for being relaxed and intentionally aimless. Perhaps, when watching Irozuku, you might wonder: "Where is this going?" For most of its run, the show does indeed feel directionless, to the point where the thematic components seem haphazardly stitched together, but by the final episode, it's made apparent that the colour motif, the magical time travel setup, and the aimless pacing all serve a purpose.


Colours, or the concept of, are undoubtedly the selling point of the show as they are the root of Hitomi's internal conflict. With such seemingly obvious symbolism, the gut reaction is immediately to decode it. However, Irozuku is a little shrewd, and the most obvious readings (depression, emotions, love, etc.) are red herrings on closer inspection. Colours don't really "represent" anything in particular; they serve as a visual cue to the audience that Hitomi is unable to experience. Full stop. Her complete achromatopsia severs her from experiencing the phenomenon of the moment. She's so wrapped up in her own preconceptions of her relationships with others that she is unable to see colour (and by extension, she is also unable to produce magic, which is viewed in this universe as a means to help, and thereby connect with, other people). It's a dramatic manifestation of her psyche, but intelligible nonetheless. Theoretically, this show wouldn't have worked as a book, since the visual euphemism is so crucial. During scenes in which we see through Hitomi's eyes, the contrast of the vibrant palette against the monochromatic world enhances the exuberance of the moment by sucking the audience into the graphic instant.


The knowledge that Hitomi must return to the future by the end is kind of a wink to the audience about the ephemerality of youth. We know that Hitomi's time with the Magic Photography Arts Club is limited, which makes the experience much more somber. Yet she ultimately finds meaning in her time with the club, and the fruits of her time traveling emerge in the final episode in which she and her elderly grandmother Kohaku "reminisce" about their shared school days. This uncanny, almost bizarre scene conflates Hitomi's past and present self quite literally; the 60-year-old photos of Hitomi with the Magic Photography Arts Club are skimmed by present day Hitomi, who has only aged a couple of weeks since then. The juxtaposition of Kohaku's genuine nostalgia against Hitomi's newfound awareness for her own "present" evokes plaintive rumination in a manner suggestive of the mono no aware of the aforementioned scene from Yi Yi.


The endgame of catharsis you expect from a show like this isn't really the point, rather the point is that the individual moments matter even though you know there will eventually be an end to them, as youth is in fact fleeting. That's why the banal, slice of life events that actually happen in the show seem like they weren't "going anywhere": they weren't. The romances, the hangouts, the club affairs, none of it really matters in regard to building up to a narrative climax. What matters is that they actually happened so Hitomi had something to look back at sentimentally and feel like she truly enjoyed experiencing.


Unfortunately, the stories comprising Hitomi's experiences in the past aren't very engaging, or at the very least, I'm unable to recall most of them. There were a couple of memorable moments, like the scene in which the club runs across a bridge in an attempt for a photo op with a night cruise, or even some of the mundane shots of some of the characters walking and talking against the streetlit night. But these glimpses into transient youth were few and far between. Most of the vignettes were too goal-oriented and relied too much on tired school cliches, which is a poor decision when the bulk of the narrative relies on such moments. Maybe Irozuku's aimlessness would have felt more justified had it more moments of genuine humanity.

So this anime is better then my evaluation of it will make it seem, theres a point at which i just couldn't deal with the dissonance between what the anime expected me to feel vs how i actually felt that exacerbated my discontent with the writing
Plot 3/10
None of the conflict/character driven plot is atrocious but the spacing that conflicts are given is really strange. Not much of the conflict feels organic, especially towards the end. that said there are interesting themes at work and the pacing issues might be a fault of adaptional... wait this is anime original? whoever wrote this script really needed toput a little more time and thought into it. 

school-life drama always runs a risk of breaking immersion really easily, and the rather sporadic nature of the driving forces in plot didn't help 


art 9/10 

good sci-fi fantasy themes with a high budget make for a great spectacle. several scene make me wish i could visit set pieces in VR, and the art generally ties in well to the rest of the work well enough

not very creative designs, pretty shallow characters. nothing all that bad but nothing that resonated with me otherwise

Irozuku Sekai no Ashita Kara was interesting and full of emotion. And as expected, it was full of color. 
Story: The story had an interesting premise, but didn't really deliver to it's full potential throughout the anime. It was rather slow paced, and it focused more on the characters for the first half of the season. We're introduced to the main character, she's abruptly sent into the past, she makes a few friends and they basically hang out for a few episodes without many events. The second part of the show picked up a bit and became more interesting, which merits the story a fairrating as the plot got much better in the final episodes.


Art: The art was very pleasing, very colorful, despite the main character's lack of ability to see color. The animation was smooth and the backgrounds were delightful and helped to build the world that the story occurred in. My only complaints were the inconsistencies with anatomy and the style the characters were drawn in- at times they appeared almost cross eyed because of the way the eyes were animated and the noses had a strange splotch of light on them constantly. Other than those things, the art was very good.


Sound: The opening was short and catchy, as well as the ending concluding each episode well. They both fit well with the show's visuals. On the last episode they played a song that wasn't the opening or the ending and it was wonderfully done and placed perfectly. The songs were enjoyable and they flowed with the show.


Character: This show focused mainly on the characters, so writing them well was really important to the success of it. Hitomi, the main character, is rather distant and aloof, which was fitting for her place in the show. She showed good character development throughout as she began to open up her friends and become more confident and social. The other characters were done well too; they were each distinct and unique people. Throughout the rather slow first half of the season, we get to know them and their relationships with each other.


Personally, I was rather disappointed with the show at first. It lacked the luster and excitement that I had seen in the trailer. I did come to enjoy it more towards the end, when the plot was able to really shine and the well-built characters were able to complete their arcs. It was a bittersweet experience as well- it didn't give us the happy ending we all expected, but something else, something that made it much more unique and valuable. So, overall I think the show was worth watching. The last episode was my favorite and it really concludes the show well, so if you can make it through the rather boring introductions, you can enjoy the bittersweet and emotionally moving end.

This is a review with only minor to no spoilers (only for the very first episode or details that really don't spoiler the story).
Irozuku is a pretty nice show with a good art and a very different story to what I'm used to and I liked it although it has some little flaws.
Story: 8/10
I liked the story a lot. It starts in the future but ends up being mostly set in our time. Where the protagonist named Hitomi was sent to by her grandmother. So she ends up in a time where her grandmother is about the same age as her and where she issupposed to learn a few things about the world and herself that might help her in her life.

The world where Hitomi lives in is almost like ours with the difference that magic is something pretty normal and there are things like magic supply shops and even some magic tools for people who aren't magicians. Hitomi and her grandmother both are witches but Hitomi doesn't like magic very much.

I like the world concept and that the show is set in a different time than the one the protagonist belongs in.


Art: 8/10

Nothing much to say here. The art is really nice and sometimes pretty colorful and feels somehow gentle to me. It adds a bittersweet and calm feeling to the show which I also liked a lot. All the characters are nicely drawn (in my opinion) and so is the whole world - especially the city lights at night look nice. I've seen anime with a more impressive art style but I think this is one of the best when it comes to the art.


Soundtrack: 7/10

The soundtrack is nice and fits the show and the scenes well but as for me it wasn't that memorable. The opening and ending both are good as well and also fit the show but they aren't going to become my favorite opening/ending.


Characters: 8/10

The characters were quite decent in my opinion, not bad but still not exceptionally good. I found all the protagonists likable and many of them get some character development, especially the female main character. I particularly loved to see how Hitomi developed with her attitude towards herself and towards others but I also liked to watch Kohaku trying to get better at magic all the time and the developments of Yuito and Asagi were also enjoyable (especially when it comes to their interaction with other people).


Enjoyment: 8/10

I liked how it felt to watch this show and see how the story progresses and the characters develop although it was quite predictable at times. Furthermore I loved how there were always some scenes that I thought were impressive with their great art and nice feeling - especially when we get to see some magic, city views or nice drawings and photo motives. I really think that the main problem with this show was the predictability and that I enjoyed it but didn't think of it as very exciting. I didn't feel the need to watch every episode as soon as it aired because it didn't give me the excitement of how the story would develop but most of the time I watched it the same day nonetheless just because of that great enjoyment and feeling of content that this show brought to me.


To be honest, when I started to watch this show on the day it started to air I really didn't think that I would enjoy it so much, that was one of my greatest 2018 anime surprises. Especially since I normally prefer watching anime with more action in it, which - let's be honest - isn't the case at all for this show.

Anyone who is considering to give it a try I can just say do it, even if you don't like it as much as I did I don't think you'll truly regret watching it.


Overall, it's a 8/10 for me!

“If you weren’t able to see colours, then maybe you would come to appreciate what’s more important standing in front of you” 
That’s one of the messages I got from watching Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara.
This is a show about discovering oneself, overcoming your fears and embracing every part of you. As I’ve watched other romance anime that have touched on similar themes and I think have executed them better (for example Your lie in April or Your name), I have to say this anime does not hold up in comparison. In fact, Irozuku Sekai is similar to Violet Evergarden where the story is reallysurface level and it’s carried by the pretty colours because it’s lacking substance. 


Plot (4/10):

A quiet, lonely girl named Hitomi is a descendant from a family of mages. Hitomi’s colour blind for unknown reasons. She is transported to the past by her grandmother Kohaku in order to rediscovery herself. This is where she becomes friends with a younger Kohaku and her classmates (because the girl is incapable of doing so in her own timeline). Her she meets a boy who’s able to bring colour to her dull and grey life. 


The premise is your typical, cliche romance series. Literally, after watching the first episode you’d be able to decipher where the story is going because it’s so generic and predictable.


The plot is thin. There weren’t any interesting sub-plots or twists that made the story more engaging. It felt like the writer knew what he wanted to do in the first and last episodes, and the middle was just padding which amounted to filler to ‘creating memories’ for Hitomi. 


The pacing was slow at the beginning and a whole lot of nothing was happening. 


Characters (5/10): 

Hitomi is a bland, quiet girl with virtually no personality. You could replace her with a mannequin in the beginning and there wouldn’t be any difference.  

She’s a generic dandere. The way Hitomi is written at times is as if she’s had the worst life ever, like she’s a victim who’s been abused her entire life. I may be exaggerating, but it annoyed me how much her friends had to baby and walk on egg shells around her at the beginning. 


However, Hitomi does grow throughout the show. The journey to the past helped Hitomi rediscovery herself. Hitomi got over her depression and became more self confident. She regained her love for magic once again. Hitomi discovered a world full of colours, which long plagued her grey existence. Hitomi found a purpose and overcame the problems she would normally run away from (finding friends, love, reconciling with her mother).


Kohaku is a fun, outgoing, confident girl- basically the exact opposite to Hitomi and a far more interesting character in my opinion.  


Aoi is the lonely art boy who falls in love with Hitomi. The underlying reason is because they brought colour into their lonely, dull lives. 


The rest of the main cast are so basic and undeveloped that I don’t feel like talking about them individually. I felt like I didn’t know anything about them except for a few character traits. You’ll end up forgetting them once the season’s over anyway.


Animation & Sound (7/10): 

One of the shows highlights is the animation was stunning. The backgrounds & scenery were detailed. The bright colour scheme made the world feel vibrant and full of life. 


The music was beautifully composed. I especially like the opening song. That being said, pretty colours isn’t enough to make up for the lack of substance. 


Overall (5/10):

The series isn’t as good as everyone makes it out to be. The story and characters aren’t complex, it has cliche troupes you see in romance anime e.g. love triangles. Magic is never defined well in this world. Hitomi and Kohaku are mages capable of using magic because plot. The fact that Hitomi may be causing a time paradox the more she messes with characters/events is a issue rarely if ever mentioned. 


Spoilers:







The ending was underwhelming.


Did Club President x Asagi a ship in the future? Did Glasses girl go to college? What ever happened to Aoi? Did he move on and find someone else? 


This was a poor conclusion to our club members. I would’ve have preferred learning more about them from pictures in the time capsule or meeting the older versions.


Aoi was a bland love interest. Him and Hitomi’s relationship lacked chemistry. When they said they loved each other it came across forced and felt like they were jumping a few steps because they didn’t progress much as friends. Hell, they never even kissed. The other relationships were underdeveloped too. For example, the Club President x Hitomi, club president x Asagi also didn’t feel anything more than friends.


There’s a lot of bad writing in this show. It’s a overhyped, mediocre romance anime.

I've come to a point where I have little to no patience for sitting through mediocre anime anymore, why? Simply because there is a vast ocean of other series that I could be watching that are actually good. I don't have to waste my time trudging in the filth that is produced season to season by the anime industry.
The question I ask myself today is, how in the hell did this anime manage to hook me in for nine episodes with my current mindset!? Maybe it was the pretty colors, maybe it was my blind faith in P.A. Works, maybe it was my want tofill a vacancy for the anime I was watching at the time, I have no clue. What I do know is that Irozuku is not good, it doesn't warrant your time nor patience, and you can find plenty of anime better than it without much effort.


Now, I want to say that Irozuku isn't horrible. If it caters to your likes then there may be a chance that you actually enjoy this series. But then I would have to ask, what exactly are your likes? Is it a mundane cast of characters? Spearheaded by the MC, Hitomi Tsukishiro, who is a walking Shrinking Violet trope? What about the uninspired character designs that would make stick figures look like masterpieces in comparison? Oh, I know!!! It's those mesmerizing rainbow colors that put you in a trance. Well..... wake up and smell the coffee!!! You have been bamboozled, swindled, fooled by the "feels" and by the potential of this series that seems more nonexistent the more episodes you watch.


So, I read the synopsis and seeing that magic was normal in the world of Irozuku, I was intrigued and eager to see what that would lead to. Long story short, it led to nothing, at least up till episode nine. Magic in this world is nothing more than a gimmick. While magic is kinda necessary given the fact that Hitomi is sent 60 years in the past, the concept of magic could have been written out of the story with not much changing. I'm not mad that magic is in the series, I'm just disappointed that it didn't enhance anything when it had the promise to.


Getting into the main plot of Irozuku, we are supposed to be following Hitomi and her growth as a individual. Hitomi is crippling shy, so the mission is to break Hitomi out of her shell so she can get out there and make friends. Being an introvert myself (albeit not to the same degree), I kinda relate to Hitomi. As a character, Hitomi starting where she was makes sense because it leaves room to grow, but mannnn is she boring. Sure, you can argue that Hitomi is a realistic character but that doesn't make her journey any less dull. Pair that with the show's sluggish pace and it makes Hitomi's uneventful adventure (Jojo reference) more apparent. It also doesn't help that the supporting characters can't disguise Hitomi's blandness since, they themselves are pretty bland as well, excluding Kohaku. Going back to Hitomi, I feel like the growth for her character is there, but it's happening too gradually. Yes, it is better to ease into development than to rush it, but considering that this series is only 13 episodes, and the fact that it's suffering because of this almost hesitant maturation, I say hit the gas and let's get rolling. There is also needless drama in this show but because I risk spoiling part of the series by expanding on this, I will refrain from talking about specifics. Let's just say that the romance triangles, squares, and pentagons, are played out.


As I said before this series is not horrible, I save that label for shows that are practically torture to watch which Irozuku isn't. This series had it's good moments, maybe even a good episode. I joked about it, but this series is  visually appealing (character designs are a different story). The contrast of the monochrome seen through Hitomi and the myriad of the colors that this series throws at you make for a good combination aesthetically. This series lives up to the name "The World in Colors." I also found some of the club member's interactions pretty funny when they went on trips, it's a shame that we didn't have more of that. The last thought I want to add is that I enjoyed Kohaku. I thought it was cool that Hitomi's future grandmother was the catalyst for Hitomi's growth and that she would give advice from the perspective of a 17 year old, while still being wise and helpful. 


To close this review out, I want to say, make your own decision on whether or not you watch this show. Make your own decision on whether or not you like this show, just be prepared for a slow burn, that may not have a grand reward at the end. Not every rainbow has a pot of gold at the end. (I'm sorry but I couldn't resist not making a rainbow joke, I'll leave now).

The following lines are not intended to be an objective review. This will be an honest opinion about a mislabeled show following a forceful viewing of almost 8 episodes.

Sound:

Character/s:

*Spoiler Free Review*
I told myself not to write anything about this anime but i couldnt help it and wrote in the forum, now writing here.
Irozuku Sekai no Ashita Kara has a strange setting. You cant really find a similar setting in any other anime. Thats why it made it really interesting and unique at the beginning. But as the anime continued, i started to see many cliches. There were love triangles that didnt contribute to the story ( it did contribute something, but it wasnt expressed well ) there was some school cliches that you can find in any shoujo anime. Thats why i gotbored in some episodes, or i watched it with any significant enjoyment. But overally i liked watching it, the story wasnt something i will remember for years but it was something that i could watch to spend some free time. 

But there is one problem. 

This anime *could* be an anime i would remember for years. 

I think the main problem was the characters. I liked the characters and i think they were interesting. But it was only at first. There was Chigusa, the funny boy. I really wanted to see more from him, but after the first half of the anime he was mostly a side character that was there to fill the scene. I really wanted to see the relationship between Chigusa and Kurumi. Also Kurumi had a potential too but they mentioned about her character only in one episode (and not in the entire episode), after that she was a side character too. Shou, the captain the *supposedly* gentleman... he was nice but after some time he just felt like an empty character. 

Asagi was a cute girl. Kohaku seemed like an okay character from beginning to the end. They didnt make her empty or enhance her character but she had some character development. 

Hitomi did have nice character development. But i should be honest at first she seemed like a boring character even though i like silent characters. 

I think my favorite character was Yuito. 

The anime revolves around the characters, because the characters started not to feel good after some point, the anime also started to feel not good enough. To sum up, the anime had really good potential and really good setup ( the first episodes ) but then rushed many things, skipped character development for many characters thats why felt incomplete in may ways.

Everything was going on like this and the last three episodes started... 

They again had some issues but i really like the message that they tried to give at the end. I like how the anime was more like Anohana rather than a classic shoujo anime. I really felt the emotions in the last episode. I really cant describe how it made me feel. I hadnt been this emotional after an anime for a long time. 

Thats another reason why i am angry at this anime.

It could be much much better, it wasted its resources though still made me feel this much. I cant imagine how i would feel if this anime didnt have this many flaws. 

Also even though ending was successful, it had something missing which devastated me emotionally. I think it was a flaw though they shouldnt leave it like that. I cant tell what it is here since it would be a big spoiler.

What the show deserved: 6/10
What I gave it: 7
What drew me in initially was mainly the fact that it was from P.A Works and I'm still looking for the next Nagi no Asukara. Add to it the bright colors, the fact the main lead couldn't see them and time travel, I got massively hyped.
The initial dialogue was my first clue: she starts talking about loving colors, and then proceeds to list a bunch of them. That adequately sums up the anime, I'd say. It could be deep, could have depth, but it falls flat.
Art & Sound:
This is the real reason I'm giving this anime a7 and not a 6. The production value was high, with wonderful use of the color palette and even the middle episodes didn't have massive drops in animation as shows tend to do. The music was also soothing, fit the atmosphere, and in some points actually did manage to tug some heartstrings; I have absolutely no complaints. 


Story & Characters:

The story premise was unique. As the show says, time travel and a lack of color just sounds like you could have a real digging of the mind, depth not many anime tend to have. Unfortunately, it didn't meet my high hopes by any means. It ended up being one of school drama and love triangles that we've seen so many times before.


What surprised me was just how many characters they had. And here's where things get interesting. By having such a long list of main-ish cast members, you either end up stereotyping everyone to the point of inducing migraines, or you  focus on one or two of them, to the expense of everyone else. Either way you'd expect some massive ignoring to happen.


Instead, they actually divided time up between everyone relatively evenly. I found this quite an achievement, and each of the SEVEN leads actually managed to leave a mark and, get this, NOT IRRITATE THE VIEWER. Don't get me wrongs, everyone was a stereotype, but not bash-my-skull-in, gouge-out-my-eyes level.


This also lead to the focus NOT being on the main characters. Although the story is about Hitomi, and her infatuation with Yuito, I didn't really feel that either of them were really in my face - a pro and possibly a con. I found it interesting. 


That space though left much to be wanted. There had to be a depth to fill the lack of focus. Either it should have focused on the relationship with her grandmother, entirely on her grandmother, maybe more time with friends, with an intense look at everyone's problems.


So the problems were just that: zero depth. Just as soon as you felt something was about to develop, they were just left for another story line, or a different character. It never let me get absorbed in anything. I do appreciate that not every character shown has to have a massive impact on the story (e.g. the random older sister, or the graduated senpai. Neither added to the story, but their existence helped add detail to the world.)


I must admit, the end was quite well done, but I only wish it reflected the rest of the show. In the end it just left me wanting more. They didn't mess anything up, per say, but there was nothing special, it lacked that extra mile, and a wonderfully set stage was left untapped and unexplored.


Here's the bottom line:

If you enjoy slice of life, and a dash of relatively well-done romance, with 8.5/10 animation, watch this, by all means. It really is a great way to spend your time. I didn't feel myself itching to get back to watching it when I was somewhere else, but watching it was peaceful. Nice. Nothing fancy, just nice.


But don't go into it thinking your life will change, because it certainly won't.

Irozuki Sekai no Ashita kara is a very simple show with very simple characters. Hitomi has some serious family problems. She doesn't cares about anything and feels responsible for what her mother gone through. Through the power of magic, she goes to the past to her grandma's generation to rekindle her emotions. 
Story: 6
Story was fairly simple with Hitomi joining a club that she felt comfortable and finding friendships and romance in it. But she has to return to the future some day and abandon the friendships forged in this timeline.
Art: 10
Art was astonishing especially since the story was about pictures, there were amazing artworksall around. Animation was also on point especially during scenes where they animate ''real life'' and ''paintings''. Most people were probably attracted firsthand due to the art.\n\n
Character :6\n
Characters were very ordinary honestly, with love triangles happening in the clique and having natural ships (3girls and 3 guys). \n\n
Enjoyment: 8\n
Most people would be satisfied with how the story unfolds, seeing Hitomi being someone who don't want to make any relationships with others to actually loving someone. Also, the Photography club makes Hitomi feels like home and treat her like family. She eventually undergone a lot of character development and by the end of the series, she becomes that cheerful girl everyone wants her to be, all thanks to the people back in the past\n\n
Overall :7\n
Why did I rate it so low even though everything seems good? Because of the potential wasted from this anime. Lots of things in the anime was not fully or not clearly explained. Many important events were summarised and was a 20seconds speech by the character. There were so many scenes which could make the audience become even more engrossed with the story and characters, which I really feel sad that they didn't adapt it. The ending scene was also done well but was underwhelming. Most would expect an Ano Hana type of goodbye but it was really below expectations.\n\n
All in all, the anime has been a great watch even with its shortcomings. Really makes you think back to those good times you had in your school clubs and with your school mates. Art was totally awesome so it is definitely worth it to check it out.

Great technical art, but a generic storyline. If you are looking for a simple, feel-good anime, this is it. Iroduku: The World in Colors is not very original or out-of-the-box. I love the magic, mage, modern, and art-focus aspect of the anime but from the first two episodes, you can basically predict the flow of the episode sequence. I mostly enjoyed the high-quality visuals and "cookie-cutter" character development. The flow is slow and clean. For some reason, Hitomi's and all the girl faces have a perpetual blush. As a character designer, I wouldnot have done this.

P.A. Works continually produces exciting and good content. I loved Shirobako, Sakura Quest, Angel Beats!, Charlotte, among many others. So my excitement was no less after watching the trailer for Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara.
To be fair, the premise is good. It's a captivating and intriguing idea, using time travel to benefit and improve one's self, and I thought that the personal battles of Hitomi were original and enticing enough to get me to watch.
However, that's where the line is drawn in terms of where the anime succeeded. Unfortunately, I think that the execution was quite poor.
The characters fall short in depth and personality. It'squite hard to grasp the intentions and motivations for any of them. Each character's personality, especially Hitomi, seems quite flat. The most exciting character to me, Kohaku, is still a typical vibrant and motivated character that you see in most anime.


The supporting cast of characters that make up the Magic Arts Photography Club (one of the focal points in the series) get left in the dust in terms of fruitful character development. The series tries to tell you that they each improve along with Hitomi in their own personal development, but it's hard to see. I commonly mistake one of the male characters for the others since they're so bland.


The art is fine. It's a bit different from most P.A. Works animation styles. I'm not a huge fan of the character designs--I think the facial proportions are a bit weird--but the environment is pretty well-designed and the colors are brought out beautifully.


I think that the series tries to make up for the lack of character depth with emotional storytelling, but it's not enough. In the moments where the characters embrace something about themselves or share an emotional moment of triumph and understanding, I'm left wondering why these characters are so emotional after being so reserved in the other scenes.


The intertwining of magic with a slice of life premise was confusing at times. Unlike well-executed magic slice of life series like Flying Witch, the use of magic in this series tends to be more of a distraction rather than naturally blending in with the story. I didn't expect the series to explain to us the fundamentals and origins of magic in that world, but I also think that it could have benefited from a more structured magic system. For example, Kohaku believes that Hitomi has some sort of "unconscious" magic that she is consistently using, but it's not very clear what the nature of that is.


Overall, this series was a disappointment for me. I'm hoping that it gets adopted into another medium, like a light novel or manga, so that the story can be more flushed out.

There were two anime this season that really were tackling the concept of depression. One hit it out of the park, and this one, did okay. Visually, this is a feast for the eyes. Even when you switch into the protagonist's black and white point of view, every frame is gorgeous. But the story itself is a mixed bag. 
My issues with the story are many fold.  First, and foremost, the romance in this show just doesn't feel all that real.  The leads don't really have bonding moments that feel organic.  Second, for most of the show the conflicts are really juststandard high school drama. The fantastical elements mostly fall into the background until late in the season. To the show's credit, the characters deal with these situations in realistic and mature fashion, but high school drama is not all that enthralling. 


Now an area of conflict that could have used more is the psychological issues of the two leads, and how they help each other cope with them. Hitomi's colorblindness is a manifestation of depression and shame for being a mage. That is a really interesting concept, but many episodes push this into the background when they could have easily had this narrative push the show through the entire season. The male lead's (his name slipped my mind, he was that memorable) hang ups about his art also could have been an interesting thread to explore, but it kind of just resolves itself for the silliest of reasons. 


Still, there are moments in this anime that are breathtakingly gorgeous. Pretty enough to keep me watching an anime I would have otherwise dropped. If you're just looking for a feast for your eyes, go for it. If you're looking for a great story, it's just not here.

On occasion, I am saddened by the fact that I was right about something.
When I see P.A Works, there remains still a linger of excitement. Even though they are the same ones who brought to life Charlotte, the same ones responsible for Another, the ones who bored me to tears with Sakura Quest, and the same ragtag band of hustlers who destroyed the unbelievable hope I held for the miserable Glasslip, every time one glances at the seasonal charts, there is always a resurgent fandom whose intent on making sure everyone knows that P.A Works is coming out with another visual spectacle.
Because a majority ofthe time, that is all reasonable viewers will come out understanding. They have trite and contrived stories, but they sure are gorgeous to look at. With the benevolent exceptions of Shirobako, Nagi no Asukara, and the Eccentric Family, there is not a single program of theirs that have failed to disappoint. 


In comes in Iroduku: A World in Colors, Hitomi Tsukishiro is a 17-year old high school student whose from a lineage of magic users, but she is monotone and stale. To remedy this, her grandmother sends Hitomi back into the past where a younger version of her grandmother resides to see if there her granddaughter can find herself. There is not a more beautiful and obvious example of a character-driven narrative, which makes one question why concepts like time travel and an ambiguous magic needed to be plot devices in the first place. 


Let me repeat: this is a character-driven narrative. If you wanted to incorporate time travel and an ambiguous magic, there would be much better ways to have them be relevant and present in the plot. They are not. Why was it necessary when it all devolves into a melodramatic romance set in a derivative high school setting? 


Here, I will need to define two words from the perspective of how I assess anime. 


First, what makes something melodramatic? Often enough, as a viewer, a program attempts to insert emotions and tones compelling enough to bring out a reaction. A show may attempt to be incredibly violent and filled with gore in an attempt to shock a viewer, making it edgy as well as melodramatic. In this example, the correct manner to address this would be to have the violent actions contain shreds of nuance. Was it earned? Was it senseless violence for the purpose of enriching the setting or the themes? Did it do so successfully or did it fail to go anywhere meaningful? Goblin Slayer would be one I reference to say it failed. The original season of Psycho Pass where it was successful. In Iroduku, the relationships are artificial and devoid of any endearing characterization to the point where we as viewers cannot buy it. While we often find adorable the idea of what they present to us, it is because we have filled in the cracks with our own experience and knowledge. P.A Works did not create a narrative that earned any of its developments. Characters are coupled up for the sake of the main romance. From the outset, Hitomi is supposed to go back in time to find herself as an individual and of course the only way she can do that is through a guy. There are two crimes: one, Hitomi needs a guy to discover herself; second, it is not a believable relationship so how could she have possibly found herself through this guy with the most shallow and unbelievable of interactions. P.A Works expects its viewers to find the content of its narrative as beautiful as its visuals, but that is the equivalent of a red herring. Visuals are meant to complement its narrative, create a synaesthesia between the story, visuals, and audio. There’s a variable here clearly nonexistent in strength. 


Second, what exactly does it mean to be derivative? Obviously, nothing is entirely original and the pursuit of an experience that is entirely original is neither realistic nor is it the ideal. Little Busters: Refrain! is clearly derivative of many visual novel adaptations, yet it is such a pinnacle in that space that it is highly enjoyable nonetheless. We strive to consume content that refines its sources more and more. Makoto Shinkai films are basically the same film over and over - I would know, as I have been consuming for them since The Place Promised in Our Early Days, and after a while, I was sticking around for the pretty visuals wondering when Shinkai would feel successful enough that he would leave the theme of forlorn and unrequited love alone. Nonetheless, he kept retreading the same ground (to a contentious degree) while spinning the premise until he hit the biggest success of his entire career in Your Name. Here he has captured the essence of the story he has been trying to tell for the better part of more than a decade. I was left completely impressed and shocked. It is the greatest experience I had in 2016. Derivative is not the principal issue a majority of the time. It is the repetition of tired ground without an ounce of innovation or personality. There is nothing that sets apart this anime from its contemporaries. There are plenty of personal growth narratives in high school settings that supersede this in every category. Golden Time does an infinitely better job doing this and it has bloody amnesia tropes ridden all about it. But it has a more humorous ensemble and character dynamics, while this one is latent and directionless hue of drab. 


Visuals look pretty. Too bad it is left to waste in something that will be forgotten by Winter 2019. To be honest, it was forgotten after the airing of the last episode. 


In all fairness, the one merit of the show is that it is consistent. Sure, consistently boring and uninspired, but it does the bare essentials. It has the plot, it has the characters, it continues on its trajectory, has an ending, and ties its subplots together and sends you along. Much can be said on how unfortunately rare a show successfully does this, when it comes to this genre in particular. 


P.A Works is a brutal and lustful behemoth. They cannot stop making you think this may be their next hit; the debuts are strong enough and brimming with potential. Then it starts to become obvious the narrative is not going anywhere. Why did I start watching this again? There’s nothing worthwhile here. It’s an artificial canvas of wonderful artwork, but the layers underneath when uncovered reveal a regrettably vapid mosaic that was better left backstage than on full display. 


[This review was copied from a blog titled "Fictional Freak", a new website where a band of college writers develop their writing by commenting on all the anime, gaming, and later literature that fascinates them or is being circulated. The original page for this review was titled "The Artificality of Iroduku: The World in Colors" and can be found here: https://www.fictionalfreak.com/anime/2018/12/30/the-artificiality-of-iroduku-a-world-in-colors]

P.A. Works, a studio that is synonymous with shows that have Slice of Life and Drama mixed together. True Tears, Angel Beats, Charlotte, Shirobako, and many more are a few examples. Irozuku Sekai no Ashita kara, was a show that I was excited for, and it ended in a way that I can only consider as fulfilling but tragic at the same time. 
Story: 5 - To be honest, it was just a slice-of-life show. Drama was mixed in the episodes, not directly, but just subtle enough for the average viewer to sense jealousy. There was a foundation to the story, which was to buildthe characters and the world. More so the characters, but it was decently executed, which is why I have it a mediocre score.



Art: 9 - THIS, is the one of the best aspects of the show, WOW, P.A. Works never dissapoints in the animation department for sure. The fireworks, vibrancy in the world, and character designs are top notch. I would consider this one of the best animated shows of this year. 



Sound: 10 - AMAZING OPENING, It's really opening



Character: 6 - This is part of the show where I have to nitpick. The characters were developed fairly well for 13 episodes. The introduction to them was comedic in a sense, and the groups dynamic was done in a way where you weren't truly bored waiting for anything to happen. The main heroine though, she was what I would call a Violet Evergarden copy. What do I mean by this, the show is about a girl finding her purpose in life. Our main heroine can't see color, which makes her lack any motivation in her current life, so she was sent to the past, to find her purpose. If any of you have watched Violet Evergarden, it's quite obvious where I'm going with this. Violet however, it's executed in short but intertwined stories that help develop Violet. So what I'm trying to say is, the main heroine at the end. It was a hopeful ending, I know we didn't want it. But with the time travel aspect added into the show, it was to be expected.

Okay so this is the first time I make a review ever. And english isn't my first language so bear with me. But I wanted to express my disappointment with this anime somehow. And yeah I haven't finished it, in fact it's still ongoing, but I just can't bring myself to finish it.
The main reason I started watching this anime is because I read that it was directed by Nagi no Asukara's director. I absolutely loved that anime, it was very enjoyable and full of emotions. So I thought this anime would be just as good. The result? Not at all.
It starts with a potentiallyinteresting plot (no spoilers) so it kinda makes you curious about how it is going to end. But the thing is, after 9 episodes I watched, nothing related to the plot has happened. I'm surprised it is not considered a slice of life anime, because I asure you IT IS. Now I normally like slice of life IF they are somewhat enjoyable. This one just isn't, it's very veeeery boring. This is where my huge disappointment comes.\n\n
Now it has some good things like the animation, aesthetic and music. But of course that is just not enough to make a good anime. I feel like the creators thought this anime would be super popular just by being pretty or something.\n\n
I'm going to set my rankings. Story: 3/10. Extremely poor given the potential it originally had. \n
Art: 8/10. Quite beautiful and colorful.\n
Sound 9/10. I looove the music, it's magical. Not to mention Nagi Yanagi sings the ending so that's a plus.\n
Characters: 3/10. Do they even have personalities? No they don't. Only the Kohaku has one. Literally. Also the romances aren't well done at all. The main couple have 0 chemistry and are overall super boring to see...\n
Enjoyment: 4/10. No words needed, it's just not enjoyable.\n
Overall: 5/10. I honestly think it does not deserve any better, regardless of the end of the anime.

So \n

What can I say? I certainly had higher hopes for this anime, and while there is certainly a lot I liked which made it enough to separate it from Slice of Life predecessors, there was also a lot it could have done better.
What I liked - 
The Art, need I say more about this? Very few anime are able to capture it's art direction so close to it's story. It's not just gorgeous, it also ties directly with the anime's core themes, and every minute of it is undeniably beautiful. 
I liked the relationship between the grandmother and the protagonist, while at first it wasall sudden and just disconnected, it became clear that the story was as much about connecting with her family as it was finding friends and learning to love life. Out of all the characters, Kohaku had surprisingly the most development, and because of her I really liked the ending.


The themes are strong and relevant. Incorporating depression and emotions with visuals was as smart as it was bittersweet. This was done better in A Silent Voice, but it was interesting here never the less.


What it could have done better - 


As good as the art is, I really wish that they played on this aspect more. Outside of seeing the contrast with the protagonist's monochromatic view and everyone else's, it really doesn't do much else even though it's core to the story.


While Kohaku was interesting, there really isn't much to define our protagonist, and even less so for it's secondary characters even though they are supposed to be the people who help Hitomi love life again. They were more bland than Violet Evergarden combined, no backstory, no personality outside the cliché, and they turned out exactly how you think they would. Also, the love triangles are so melodramatically boring.


The themes are strong and relevant, but rarely explored. The theme here is the story, but throughout the 13 episodes there is very little happening, even the protagonist has no idea whats going on or what she is supposed to do up until the end. It's themes are simply drowned by the excessive amount of irrelevant filler that make up this anime and it's a dire shame since it really had potential.

Ended up giving a 6 for this show, could've been a 7 with some major changes to the plot. Then again I don't really like pure romance/drama series so I could be somewhat biased against this but I really don't feel like this deserves a 7.
This is a time- travelling series about a girl who has lost her ability to see colors for reasons I cannot mention without spoilers. Her grandmother sends her back in time in hopes that she could experience a more fun youth, instead of moping around being super pessimistic(this is her the entire series). You'd think that time- travel sounds likea super risky gamble where a billion things could go wrong but none of the characters seem worried so neither was I. 


+ Great visual values. The characters look kind of generic but the buildings and landscapes look simply gorgeous. I personally liked it a lot.

+ Great music. I really liked both the OP and ED and listened to them on my own a couple of times. There is also some awesome BGM during some of the animation "wow"- moments. Overall adds a good bit of spice.

+ Some great movie like "magical moments" I had to go back and rewatch.


+/- Voice actors seem like good picks though the female voices' high pitch tends to tire my ears out as usual. MC's voice is very bland.


- The plot... there isn't really a lot of it? I can't really talk about it without risking to spoil the little there is but, no, this "story" is just about nostalgia and memories, nothing really happens here.

- The characters are, like I said, the fairly generic, ultra-positive Japanese High School students. 13 episodes being short enough as it is, it's hard to get emotionally attached to these talking dolls. 

- The magic element seems like it was just slapped on the top of this show, don't expect any Harry Potter- level of depth from this magical world. People don't seem to use magic for really anything else but some light entertainment.

As most of the high ranking reviews made this series out to be either mediocre or just decent, I think I need to do it some justice, for anyone cares enough to go down the list. And so, there will be some minor spoiler, but as those are going to be key points for me, I think you need to be warned.
First thing first, for story line, Irozuku Sekai no Ashita Kara (I'll be calling it with just Irozuku, instead of any official abbreviation it might have) is not all that good. You basically have 5 threads that went down the series, that's pretty impressivefor a series lasting only 13 episodes, I think. But, if you really look at it, it's not really anything new. First thread, time travel and the inevitable outcome of it. Second thread, magic and what comes with talent in magic (or anything for that matter). Third thread, character's disability (might sound overboard, but that's the best word came to my mind). Fourth, worries about what to do in future for young ones. Fifth, romance.


It's nothing new really, you might even compare them to many other series, such as Nagi no Asukara, as I saw someone people noted. But, the way those threads were woven into each other was actually great to me, at least. 


Female lead/main character/protagonist is basically, disabled as in she's unable to see color, and you can see why right away, she's shutting herself out and always seems gloomy. One day, she just got sent off to the past for almost no reason but to satisfy another character's wish. Really, it was arbitrarily done. The reasons didn't get to be revealed until last episode too. But heck, there are other ways to perform therapies. Yes, the reasons has "recovery of ability to see color" for the protagonist included. But sending her back to the past using magic and force your past self to research the magic isn't quite the best way to do it, really. And it wasn't even revealed by words as protagonist realizes it too. That really kills off any adventure's purpose set for character development. But then, it springs several more threads into existence to keep the series going.


Romance, the one thing you can't seem to get away in works with a female lead. Protagonist being a time traveler, a magic user (or mage), a disabled, and a meek, beautiful girl is like a flag for romance from the get go. And of course, you see 2 guys in that kind of relationship with her, as in 2 guys have feelings for her and actually competed for it, kind of. A simple shoujo romance went down, with happy ending to the relationships. Yay, good thing, right? It's not explicitly shown, but you can really see how it plays out for the characters, which is nice. Just nice. But then, the dilemma is that the convergence of time flow will not allow alteration. Stein;Gates viewers might have seen enough of that, really. So, friendship, romance and all that junk will have to go to the dustbin for 60 years. Suck to be them. However, that's the beauty of it. Like in 5cm/s, it's beautiful, but unrequited. Yet, they still reach out to each others, still cure each others' illness/disabilities.


Yes, disabilities. I did say they have disabilities. Not all of them, but they do. Yamabuki Shou was a blockhead while being sensual and it hurts him, it's a minor disability and you can live with it. Kazano Asagi, she's meek and inactive. It hurts her too, in lots of way. Kawai Kurumi, she's nothing special while everyone else is. It doesn't hurt her, but it brings her down. Aoi Yuito, talented, but isn't motivated and actually feel repressive on his favorites. Tsukishiro Hitomi, talented but it leads to a trauma for her and directly caused her to become actually disabled. These are what happen to youngsters. Basically, this is where the messages are. And also, the basic solution is "to find the right person to help you". Nothing I didn't see before.


But, it's refreshing how the problems arise and resolve so naturally. 2 guys competing over 1 girl, 1 confesses and shot down, the other takes sometime  to know he's winner and confess. Worries about future eased up by people who cares about you telling it's fine to take it easy to think. Friends who are rivals in love go back to good friends for knowing how it goes with each other. Love and encouragement last through time so the two can bring happiness to each other. How happiness is more than just happiness. It's actually very philosophical how problems are solved. I still don't sit well with how a mutual love became unrequited romance, but it's beautiful too so I guess it's fine. 


Writing up to this point, I kind of lost track of what I wanted to say, but to sum it up, Irozuku was an enjoyable series to me with how well stuff are related, how it's not hard to see myself in there, how realistic its depiction of relationships is, how "beautiful" every emotion, feeling, piece of memories can be... It's not bad, it's not good either, but it's somehow strangely soothing once you went through it. Personally, I wouldn't really recommend Irozuku to any young viewers though. Because it's more of something older people can understand. But, it should be a good series to younger viewers (around highschool, college), though they might not like it the first time around unless they can relate themselves hard with it.

No Spoilers.
This series is an extremely visually-intensive show that focuses itself primarily on the deep characters it uses to convey its plot.  The plot itself is engaging right from the start, and in my case it pulled me from a sort of initial derision to instant engagement when they introduced time travel, which I usually find a difficult subject for anime writers.  The feeling of full immersion never left me the entire time, and I adore the way they represented their magic in the everyday world.  Honestly, lesser artwork would have outright killed this show, because the less sensical parts of theworld seem less prominent when you're being bombarded by pretty colors.


That said I didn't give the show a 10, for the following reasons.  The plotline has a solid baseline of awesomeness but doesn't do much to capitalize on that except display typical high school shenanigans.  The author has a lot of room to work with within the constructed world they've made and really doesn't use it.  Also, while the show rides on some pretty deep characters, some of the characters are lacking in depth by comparison, and a lot of the interaction seems very stiff.  But all in all it's still above average in all qualities, with absolutely stunning art and sound.


I recommend this anime for anyone who likes really pretty stuff, or who likes Slice of Life anime with supernatural twists.  It gave me a really similar feel to Violet Evergarden.

This show is kind of like a cake that is decorated beautifully, but where the flavour doesn't live up to the appearance.
Story 7/10
The story is set in a world with magic and initially starts 60 years into the future, but immediately starts of by sending our protagonist to the past with time magic. The magic is often something that is just present, but not really the primary focus of the show. Besides the magic the setting is basically modern day Japan and the show doesn’t really do anything crazy with it. 
The plot of the show is a sweet tale about an emotionless girl wholost the ability to see colours and learns how to open up to people. Right from the start the story shows some promise, but it never really lives up to its potential. However that doesn’t mean the story is bad. In fact the story is quite good, but it drags out a bit in the middle. The finale is the emotional highlight of the show and it definitely feels earned. The dialogue in the show is top notch and feels very natural.


Art 9/10

The show looks absolutely gorgeous, and makes great use of lighting. The backgrounds look awesome. The colour palette is very natural, but the show also likes to play with colours as the main character is colourblind. Character design is great as well, all the characters look very natural, the only exceptions being the hair colours of the magic characters. The animation is fairly fluid, but not all that special in comparison with the art.


Sound 7/10

The sound design is very solid, but not necessarily anything special. The magic sounds nice and the other effects sound fairly natural. The music enhances the scenes in which it is played. The voice acting is good and especially the main character does a great job conveying the growth of the character with voice acting.


Character 7/10

The characters in the show all have their own personalities and each and every one of them feels like a real person. Most of them also show some clear growth over the course of the show. The group of characters together also feel like I could go outside and meet people like them. There aren’t that many side characters, but the ones that do pop up aren’t anything special.


Enjoyment 7/10

The show is a great watch with satisfying progression from start to finish. Not only is the show satisfying to watch it is also amazing eye candy. There were a few parts where I got a bit annoyed at the series, but never enough to take away from my enjoyment.


Overall 7/10

Let's be honest, the actual content of this anime isn't the greatest. But that isn't the point of the anime. Even though the story itself feels short-lived and not very developed, the art and animation remains beautiful without a doubt. In almost every aspect in terms of animation, it has went above and beyond. But for actual plot and story, it was very short and definitely would have done better if more episodes were added. Worth a watch for the art and animation, but not much else.
The characters were all laid out and had good story behind them all, but it felt as if notenough time were spent on each persons story to have the viewers (us) really care much about them. We will know their backstory, but not really "connect" with the character themselves.\n\n
This anime is basically an excuse to make amazing and awesome art and animation. The best I've seen in a long time. Focuses primarily and how you can view the world differently and how beautiful things come from everyday life and so on and so forth.

This anime is quite relaxing and inspiring. The story develops at its own pace, not rushing things and not making long pauses. You won't find here any evil plots or mind boggling time travel mechanics. Everything in the story is rather simple, and sometimes even reduced to quite basic elements. Like characters, for example. 
Story-wise, everything is written in pastel tones with small areas of bright color to add accents. I think, it suits the mood of the anime well, and provides audience with a clear view at what is important in the anime.
The important things are in line with the genre: friendship and love,pursuit of the goals, growing up. But these important things are shown in somewhat unusual way, with some magic involved in everyday life (but not too much), so it makes all the world of difference.


The romance part of the anime will stir some feelings inside of you, but not in a way, that you feel like a wretch the whole day afterwards. I would say, that this part is quite gentle, like the anime itself. More like something to think about, but not to dwell too much. 


If you would like a monochrome slice of life with a bit of magic in it, don't look any further, it gently landed in your hands like a feather, and will probably be swept away from your mind like a feather too.
